items.title: I can describe thermal energy as the sum of random kinetic and potential energies of particles
items.what: Thermal energy is the total of all the random kinetic energies (movement) and potential energies (interactions between particles) of the atoms and molecules in an object or system.
items.why: This definition explains why objects with different masses at the same temperature contain different amounts of thermal energy, and why adding energy can increase temperature.
items.example: A cup of water at 80°C has less total thermal energy than a bathtub of water at 40°C, even though the cup is hotter. The bathtub has many more molecules, so the sum of all their energies is greater.

subtopic.name: Temperature and Thermal Energy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of thermal energy and temperature, including how they relate to the motion and energy of particles. You will learn to distinguish between these two quantities and convert between temperature scales.
subtopic.why: Understanding the difference between thermal energy and temperature is essential for explaining everyday phenomena like why tiny sparks from a sparkler do not burn you despite being over 1000°C, and for solving problems involving heat transfer.

items.title: I can explain that temperature increases and decreases are related to changes in thermal energy
items.what: When thermal energy is added to a system, the temperature generally increases. When thermal energy is removed, the temperature generally decreases. Temperature indicates the average kinetic energy of particles.
items.why: This relationship helps predict which direction heat will flow between objects and explains why thermometers are useful for determining heat transfer direction.
items.example: Sparkler sparks at 1000°C landing on your skin do not burn you because they contain very few molecules and therefore very little total thermal energy, despite their high temperature.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of thermal energy and temperature, including how they relate to the motion and energy of particles. You will learn to distinguish between these two quantities and convert between temperature scales.
subtopic.why: Understanding the difference between thermal energy and temperature is essential for explaining everyday phenomena like why tiny sparks from a sparkler do not burn you despite being over 1000°C, and for solving problems involving heat transfer.

items.title: I can convert temperatures between Celsius and kelvin scales
items.what: To convert from Celsius to kelvin, add 273.15 to the Celsius value. To convert from kelvin to Celsius, subtract 273.15. Both scales have the same size degree.
items.why: The kelvin scale is required for many physics calculations, including Wien's law and gas laws, because it starts at absolute zero where particles have effectively no kinetic energy.
items.example: Room temperature of 20°C equals 293.15 K. The boiling point of water at 100°C equals 373.15 K. Absolute zero at 0 K equals -273.15°C.

subtopic.why: Understanding the difference between thermal energy and temperature is essential for explaining everyday phenomena like why tiny sparks from a sparkler do not burn you despite being over 1000°C, and for solving problems involving heat transfer.

items.title: I can explain why there are no negative temperatures on the kelvin scale
items.what: The kelvin scale starts at absolute zero (0 K), which corresponds to the state where molecules have effectively zero kinetic energy. It is physically impossible to remove more energy from this state.
items.why: Understanding absolute zero helps explain fundamental limits in physics and why the kelvin scale is used in scientific calculations involving energy and temperature ratios.
items.example: At 0 K (-273.15°C), particles have the minimum possible energy. You cannot cool something below this because there is no more thermal energy to remove.

subtopic.name: Temperature and Thermal Energy
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of thermal energy and temperature, including how they relate to the motion and energy of particles. You will learn to distinguish between these two quantities and convert between temperature scales.
subtopic.why: Understanding the difference between thermal energy and temperature is essential for explaining everyday phenomena like why tiny sparks from a sparkler do not burn you despite being over 1000°C, and for solving problems involving heat transfer.

items.title: I can describe conduction as thermal energy transfer through particle interactions in solids
items.what: Conduction occurs when vibrating particles in a hotter region transfer energy to neighbouring particles through collisions and interactions. In metals, free electrons also carry energy. It is most significant in solids where particles are closely packed.
items.why: Understanding conduction explains why metals conduct heat well (free electrons), why insulation works, and why you can walk on hot coals without burning your feet (charcoal conducts poorly).
items.example: Copper has a thermal conductivity 8500 times greater than fibreglass. This is why saucepans have copper bases (good conduction) but insulated handles (poor conduction).

subtopic.name: Thermal Energy Transfer
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four mechanisms by which thermal energy transfers between objects and systems: conduction, convection, radiation, and evaporation. Each mechanism operates differently and dominates in different situations.
subtopic.why: Understanding these transfer mechanisms explains everyday phenomena from why metal feels colder than wood at the same temperature, to how sea breezes form, to how the Sun's energy reaches Earth through the vacuum of space.

items.title: I can describe convection as thermal energy transfer through bulk fluid movement
items.what: Convection transfers thermal energy through the physical movement of fluids (liquids and gases). Warmer fluid rises because it is less dense, while cooler fluid sinks, creating circulation patterns called convection currents.
items.why: Convection drives weather patterns, ocean currents, and heating systems. It explains phenomena like sea breezes during the day and land breezes at night.
items.example: During a sunny day, land heats faster than the ocean. Hot air rises over the land, drawing cooler air from over the ocean, creating a sea breeze. At night, the pattern reverses.

subtopic.name: Thermal Energy Transfer
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four mechanisms by which thermal energy transfers between objects and systems: conduction, convection, radiation, and evaporation. Each mechanism operates differently and dominates in different situations.
subtopic.why: Understanding these transfer mechanisms explains everyday phenomena from why metal feels colder than wood at the same temperature, to how sea breezes form, to how the Sun's energy reaches Earth through the vacuum of space.

items.title: I can describe radiation as thermal energy transfer via electromagnetic waves
items.what: All objects above 0 K emit electromagnetic radiation. This radiation can travel through a vacuum (unlike conduction and convection) and is the only way thermal energy can transfer through empty space.
items.why: Radiation is how the Sun's energy reaches Earth across the vacuum of space. The wavelength of emitted radiation depends on temperature, which is why hot objects can glow red or white.
items.example: The Sun emits radiation that travels 150 million km through space to warm Earth. An outdoor radiant heater warms people without heating the air between the heater and the people.

subtopic.name: Thermal Energy Transfer
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four mechanisms by which thermal energy transfers between objects and systems: conduction, convection, radiation, and evaporation. Each mechanism operates differently and dominates in different situations.
subtopic.why: Understanding these transfer mechanisms explains everyday phenomena from why metal feels colder than wood at the same temperature, to how sea breezes form, to how the Sun's energy reaches Earth through the vacuum of space.

items.title: I can explain evaporative cooling using a kinetic energy model
items.what: In a liquid, molecules have a range of kinetic energies. The most energetic molecules near the surface can escape as gas, carrying away more than the average energy. This reduces the average kinetic energy of remaining molecules, cooling the liquid.
items.why: Evaporative cooling explains why sweating cools you down, why wet clothes feel cold, and how technologies like the Coolgardie safe and evaporative air conditioners work.
items.example: A Coolgardie safe keeps food cool by allowing water to evaporate from damp hessian covering. The most energetic water molecules escape, taking thermal energy with them and cooling the interior.

subtopic.name: Thermal Energy Transfer
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four mechanisms by which thermal energy transfers between objects and systems: conduction, convection, radiation, and evaporation. Each mechanism operates differently and dominates in different situations.
subtopic.why: Understanding these transfer mechanisms explains everyday phenomena from why metal feels colder than wood at the same temperature, to how sea breezes form, to how the Sun's energy reaches Earth through the vacuum of space.

items.title: I can identify which transfer mechanism dominates in different situations
items.what: Conduction dominates in solids, convection dominates in fluids, radiation can occur through any medium including vacuum, and evaporation only occurs at liquid surfaces. Multiple mechanisms often operate simultaneously.
items.why: Identifying the dominant mechanism helps solve practical problems like designing insulation, understanding weather, or explaining why double-glazed windows reduce heat loss.
items.example: A vacuum flask reduces all transfer mechanisms: vacuum prevents conduction and convection, silvered surfaces reflect radiation, and a stopper prevents evaporation.

subtopic.name: Thermal Energy Transfer
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the four mechanisms by which thermal energy transfers between objects and systems: conduction, convection, radiation, and evaporation. Each mechanism operates differently and dominates in different situations.
subtopic.why: Understanding these transfer mechanisms explains everyday phenomena from why metal feels colder than wood at the same temperature, to how sea breezes form, to how the Sun's energy reaches Earth through the vacuum of space.

items.title: I can define specific heat capacity and state its units
items.what: Specific heat capacity (c) is the energy required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of a material by 1 K. Its units are J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹. Different materials have different specific heat capacities.
items.why: Specific heat capacity determines how much energy is needed to heat or cool a substance, explaining why water takes longer to heat than metal and why coastal areas have milder climates.
items.example: Water has a specific heat capacity of 4190 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹, while copper has only 385 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹. This means water requires about 11 times more energy per kg per degree than copper.

subtopic.name: Heating and Cooling Calculations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the quantitative relationship between thermal energy, mass, specific heat capacity, and temperature change. You will learn to use the formula Q = mcΔT to calculate energy transfers during heating and cooling.
subtopic.why: These calculations are essential for practical applications like determining how long a kettle takes to boil, designing heating systems, understanding why water moderates coastal climates, and solving energy conservation problems.

items.title: I can use Q = mcΔT to calculate energy for temperature changes
items.what: The formula Q = mcΔT calculates the thermal energy (Q in joules) needed to change the temperature of a mass (m in kg) of material with specific heat capacity (c) by a temperature change (ΔT in K or °C).
items.why: This formula allows you to calculate heating requirements, predict final temperatures when objects exchange heat, and design systems involving thermal energy transfer.
items.example: To heat 2 kg of water from 20°C to 100°C: Q = 2 × 4190 × 80 = 670,400 J = 670 kJ.

subtopic.name: Heating and Cooling Calculations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the quantitative relationship between thermal energy, mass, specific heat capacity, and temperature change. You will learn to use the formula Q = mcΔT to calculate energy transfers during heating and cooling.
subtopic.why: These calculations are essential for practical applications like determining how long a kettle takes to boil, designing heating systems, understanding why water moderates coastal climates, and solving energy conservation problems.

items.title: I can rearrange Q = mcΔT to solve for any variable
items.what: The formula can be rearranged to find mass (m = Q/cΔT), specific heat capacity (c = Q/mΔT), or temperature change (ΔT = Q/mc) depending on what information is given.
items.why: Being able to rearrange the formula allows you to solve a wider range of problems, including determining unknown specific heat capacities experimentally.
items.example: A 1.5 kg block gains 4500 J of thermal energy and its temperature rises by 5°C. Its specific heat capacity is c = 4500/(1.5 × 5) = 600 J kg⁻¹ K⁻¹.

subtopic.name: Heating and Cooling Calculations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the quantitative relationship between thermal energy, mass, specific heat capacity, and temperature change. You will learn to use the formula Q = mcΔT to calculate energy transfers during heating and cooling.
subtopic.why: These calculations are essential for practical applications like determining how long a kettle takes to boil, designing heating systems, understanding why water moderates coastal climates, and solving energy conservation problems.

items.title: I can apply conservation of energy to thermal equilibrium problems
items.what: When objects at different temperatures are in contact in an insulated system, thermal energy transfers from the hotter to the cooler object until both reach the same final temperature. Energy lost by one equals energy gained by the other.
items.why: This principle allows you to predict final temperatures when mixing substances, such as adding ice to a drink or mixing hot and cold water.
items.example: If 500 g of an alloy at 20°C is placed in 500 g of water at 80°C and they reach 70°C, the alloy gained energy equal to what the water lost: 500 × c × 50 = 500 × 4190 × 10.

subtopic.why: These calculations are essential for practical applications like determining how long a kettle takes to boil, designing heating systems, understanding why water moderates coastal climates, and solving energy conservation problems.

items.title: I can explain why water's high specific heat capacity affects climate
items.what: Water's high specific heat capacity means it absorbs and releases large amounts of energy with relatively small temperature changes. This moderates temperature extremes near large bodies of water.
items.why: This explains why coastal areas have milder climates than inland areas, why lakes rarely freeze solid, and why water is used for cooling engines and storing thermal energy.
items.example: On hot days, the ocean absorbs thermal energy with minimal temperature rise. On cold nights, it releases this energy, preventing extreme temperature drops in coastal areas.

subtopic.why: These calculations are essential for practical applications like determining how long a kettle takes to boil, designing heating systems, understanding why water moderates coastal climates, and solving energy conservation problems.

items.title: I can define specific latent heat and distinguish between fusion and vaporisation
items.what: Specific latent heat (L) is the energy per kilogram needed to change the state of a substance without changing its temperature. Latent heat of fusion is for solid-liquid changes; latent heat of vaporisation is for liquid-gas changes.
items.why: Latent heat explains why temperature remains constant during phase changes despite continuous heating, and why vaporisation requires much more energy than melting.
items.example: Water's latent heat of fusion is 334 kJ kg⁻¹ (melting ice), while its latent heat of vaporisation is 2256 kJ kg⁻¹ (boiling water). Vaporisation requires nearly 7 times more energy.

subtopic.name: Changes of State
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy involved in phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states. You will learn about latent heat and use Q = mL to calculate energy for melting, freezing, vaporisation, and condensation.
subtopic.why: Understanding phase changes explains why ice cools drinks so effectively, why steam burns are worse than boiling water burns, and why energy is absorbed or released during melting and freezing.

items.title: I can use Q = mL to calculate energy for phase changes
items.what: The formula Q = mL calculates the thermal energy (Q in joules) needed to change the state of a mass (m in kg) of a substance with specific latent heat (L in J kg⁻¹). Temperature does not change during the phase transition.
items.why: This formula allows you to calculate energy requirements for melting, freezing, boiling, and condensing, which is essential for refrigeration, cooking, and industrial processes.
items.example: To melt 2 kg of ice at 0°C to water at 0°C: Q = 2 × 334,000 = 668,000 J = 668 kJ.

subtopic.name: Changes of State
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy involved in phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states. You will learn about latent heat and use Q = mL to calculate energy for melting, freezing, vaporisation, and condensation.
subtopic.why: Understanding phase changes explains why ice cools drinks so effectively, why steam burns are worse than boiling water burns, and why energy is absorbed or released during melting and freezing.

items.title: I can interpret heating curves showing temperature and phase changes
items.what: A heating curve shows temperature vs time (or energy added) for a substance being heated. Sloped sections show temperature rising; flat sections (plateaus) show phase changes where energy goes into breaking bonds rather than raising temperature.
items.why: Heating curves visually demonstrate how energy is used differently during temperature changes versus phase changes, and help identify melting and boiling points.
items.example: When heating ice from -20°C to steam: temperature rises to 0°C, stays flat while ice melts, rises to 100°C, stays flat while water boils, then rises again as steam heats.

subtopic.name: Changes of State
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy involved in phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states. You will learn about latent heat and use Q = mL to calculate energy for melting, freezing, vaporisation, and condensation.
subtopic.why: Understanding phase changes explains why ice cools drinks so effectively, why steam burns are worse than boiling water burns, and why energy is absorbed or released during melting and freezing.

items.title: I can explain why energy is released during condensation and freezing
items.what: When a substance changes from gas to liquid (condensation) or liquid to solid (freezing), bonds form between molecules. This releases the same amount of energy that was required to break those bonds during the reverse process.
items.why: This explains why steam burns are particularly severe (steam releases latent heat of vaporisation when it condenses on skin), and why freezers must remove thermal energy from water to make ice.
items.example: Steam at 100°C condensing on your hand releases 2256 kJ per kg as it becomes water, causing worse burns than contact with boiling water at the same temperature.

subtopic.name: Changes of State
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy involved in phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states. You will learn about latent heat and use Q = mL to calculate energy for melting, freezing, vaporisation, and condensation.
subtopic.why: Understanding phase changes explains why ice cools drinks so effectively, why steam burns are worse than boiling water burns, and why energy is absorbed or released during melting and freezing.

items.title: I can solve problems combining temperature changes and phase changes
items.what: Many problems require calculating energy for both temperature changes (Q = mcΔT) and phase changes (Q = mL), then adding these together. Remember that different phases may have different specific heat capacities.
items.why: Real-world heating and cooling often involves both processes, such as heating ice to water to steam, or cooling a drink with ice cubes.
items.example: To convert 1 kg of ice at -20°C to water at 20°C: (1) heat ice to 0°C: Q₁ = 1 × 2093 × 20 = 41,860 J, (2) melt ice: Q₂ = 1 × 334,000 = 334,000 J, (3) heat water to 20°C: Q₃ = 1 × 4190 × 20 = 83,800 J. Total = 459,660 J.

subtopic.name: Changes of State
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy involved in phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states. You will learn about latent heat and use Q = mL to calculate energy for melting, freezing, vaporisation, and condensation.
subtopic.why: Understanding phase changes explains why ice cools drinks so effectively, why steam burns are worse than boiling water burns, and why energy is absorbed or released during melting and freezing.

items.title: I can describe the key features of a blackbody radiator
items.what: A blackbody is a theoretical object that absorbs all electromagnetic radiation falling on it and emits radiation with maximum efficiency. The spectrum of emitted radiation depends only on temperature, not on the material.
items.why: Many real objects (stars, planets, heated metals) behave approximately as blackbodies, making this model useful for predicting their radiation properties and temperatures.
items.example: The Sun can be modelled as a blackbody with a surface temperature of about 5778 K. All blackbodies at this temperature emit the same spectrum of radiation, regardless of composition.

subtopic.name: Blackbody Radiation and Wien's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the properties of blackbody radiators, how the spectrum of emitted radiation relates to temperature, and how to use Wien's law to calculate peak wavelengths from temperature and vice versa.
subtopic.why: Understanding blackbody radiation explains how we can determine the temperature of stars from their colour, how infrared thermometers work, and forms the foundation for understanding Earth's energy balance and climate.

items.title: I can use Wien's law to calculate peak wavelength from temperature
items.what: Wien's law states that λₘₐₓ × T = 2.898 × 10⁻³ m K, where λₘₐₓ is the peak wavelength emitted and T is the temperature in kelvin. Higher temperatures produce shorter peak wavelengths.
items.why: This law allows calculation of the peak emission wavelength of any object modelled as a blackbody, which is essential for understanding why hot objects change colour as they heat up.
items.example: For the Sun at 5778 K: λₘₐₓ = 2.898 × 10⁻³ / 5778 = 5.01 × 10⁻⁷ m = 501 nm (green-yellow visible light).

subtopic.name: Blackbody Radiation and Wien's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the properties of blackbody radiators, how the spectrum of emitted radiation relates to temperature, and how to use Wien's law to calculate peak wavelengths from temperature and vice versa.
subtopic.why: Understanding blackbody radiation explains how we can determine the temperature of stars from their colour, how infrared thermometers work, and forms the foundation for understanding Earth's energy balance and climate.

items.title: I can use Wien's law to calculate temperature from peak wavelength
items.what: Rearranging Wien's law gives T = 2.898 × 10⁻³ / λₘₐₓ. By measuring the peak wavelength of radiation from an object, we can determine its temperature without physical contact.
items.why: This is how infrared thermometers measure temperature and how astronomers determine the surface temperatures of distant stars from their light spectra.
items.example: A forehead thermometer detects peak radiation at about 9.4 μm. Temperature = 2.898 × 10⁻³ / (9.4 × 10⁻⁶) = 308 K = 35°C.

subtopic.name: Blackbody Radiation and Wien's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the properties of blackbody radiators, how the spectrum of emitted radiation relates to temperature, and how to use Wien's law to calculate peak wavelengths from temperature and vice versa.
subtopic.why: Understanding blackbody radiation explains how we can determine the temperature of stars from their colour, how infrared thermometers work, and forms the foundation for understanding Earth's energy balance and climate.

items.title: I can describe how a blackbody spectrum changes with temperature
items.what: As temperature increases, the blackbody curve shifts to shorter wavelengths (peak moves left) and the total area under the curve increases dramatically. Hotter objects emit more energy at all wavelengths.
items.why: This relationship explains why objects glow different colours at different temperatures (red hot to white hot) and why the Sun emits vastly more energy than Earth.
items.example: At 3500 K, an object glows red with peak around 830 nm. At 5500 K, it appears white with peak around 530 nm, and emits roughly 6 times more total energy.

subtopic.name: Blackbody Radiation and Wien's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the properties of blackbody radiators, how the spectrum of emitted radiation relates to temperature, and how to use Wien's law to calculate peak wavelengths from temperature and vice versa.
subtopic.why: Understanding blackbody radiation explains how we can determine the temperature of stars from their colour, how infrared thermometers work, and forms the foundation for understanding Earth's energy balance and climate.

items.title: I can compare total energy emitted by objects at different temperatures using graphs
items.what: The total energy emitted by a blackbody is represented by the area under its emission spectrum curve. Comparing areas under curves for different temperatures shows how dramatically emission increases with temperature.
items.why: This graphical method helps visualise why small temperature changes can produce large changes in radiated energy, which is crucial for understanding climate sensitivity.
items.example: Comparing blackbody curves for 5500 K and 3500 K, the area under the 5500 K curve is much larger, showing it emits significantly more total energy across all wavelengths.

subtopic.name: Blackbody Radiation and Wien's Law
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the properties of blackbody radiators, how the spectrum of emitted radiation relates to temperature, and how to use Wien's law to calculate peak wavelengths from temperature and vice versa.
subtopic.why: Understanding blackbody radiation explains how we can determine the temperature of stars from their colour, how infrared thermometers work, and forms the foundation for understanding Earth's energy balance and climate.

items.title: I can describe Earth's energy budget in terms of incoming and outgoing radiation
items.what: Earth receives about 340 W m⁻² of solar radiation on average. About 29% is reflected; the rest is absorbed by the surface and atmosphere. Earth radiates infrared energy to space, and when input exceeds output, the planet warms.
items.why: The energy budget framework shows that Earth's temperature depends on the balance between energy received and energy radiated. Any factor affecting this balance can cause warming or cooling.
items.example: According to IPCC data, there is currently a residual imbalance of about 0.8 W m⁻² where Earth receives more energy than it radiates, causing gradual warming.

subtopic.name: Global Warming and Climate
subtopic.what: This subtopic applies concepts of thermal energy transfer, electromagnetic radiation, and blackbody physics to understanding Earth's energy budget, the greenhouse effect, and global warming.
subtopic.why: Understanding the physics of climate helps explain how small changes in atmospheric composition can affect global temperatures, why Earth's average temperature is warming, and how different factors influence the energy balance of our planet.

items.title: I can explain the role of greenhouse gases in back radiation
items.what: Greenhouse gases (water vapour, CO₂, methane) absorb infrared radiation emitted by Earth's surface and re-radiate it in all directions, including back toward the surface. This back radiation warms the surface beyond what direct sunlight would achieve.
items.why: The greenhouse effect is natural and necessary for life on Earth, but increasing greenhouse gas concentrations enhance back radiation, causing additional warming.
items.example: Earth's surface radiates about 400 W m⁻². Most of this is absorbed by greenhouse gases, which produce about 340 W m⁻² of back radiation to the surface.

subtopic.name: Global Warming and Climate
subtopic.what: This subtopic applies concepts of thermal energy transfer, electromagnetic radiation, and blackbody physics to understanding Earth's energy budget, the greenhouse effect, and global warming.
subtopic.why: Understanding the physics of climate helps explain how small changes in atmospheric composition can affect global temperatures, why Earth's average temperature is warming, and how different factors influence the energy balance of our planet.

items.title: I can explain the atmospheric window and why some radiation escapes directly to space
items.what: The atmospheric window refers to wavelengths of infrared radiation (roughly 8-13 μm) that are not strongly absorbed by atmospheric gases. About 40 W m⁻² of surface radiation escapes directly to space through this window.
items.why: The atmospheric window represents a cooling pathway that is relatively unaffected by greenhouse gases. Understanding it helps explain why not all surface radiation is trapped.
items.example: Only about 10% of the infrared radiation emitted by Earth's surface escapes directly through the atmospheric window; the remaining 90% is absorbed by the atmosphere.

subtopic.name: Global Warming and Climate
subtopic.what: This subtopic applies concepts of thermal energy transfer, electromagnetic radiation, and blackbody physics to understanding Earth's energy budget, the greenhouse effect, and global warming.
subtopic.why: Understanding the physics of climate helps explain how small changes in atmospheric composition can affect global temperatures, why Earth's average temperature is warming, and how different factors influence the energy balance of our planet.

items.title: I can describe how convection and evaporation transfer energy from the surface to the atmosphere
items.what: Besides radiation, thermal energy moves from Earth's surface to the atmosphere through convection (rising warm air, about 5% of incoming solar) and evaporation/latent heat (about 25% of incoming solar).
items.why: These non-radiative transfers are significant parts of Earth's energy budget, showing that radiation alone does not fully describe energy flow in the climate system.
items.example: When water evaporates from the ocean surface, it carries latent heat into the atmosphere. When this water vapour condenses as clouds or rain, it releases this energy, warming the atmosphere.

subtopic.name: Global Warming and Climate
subtopic.what: This subtopic applies concepts of thermal energy transfer, electromagnetic radiation, and blackbody physics to understanding Earth's energy budget, the greenhouse effect, and global warming.
subtopic.why: Understanding the physics of climate helps explain how small changes in atmospheric composition can affect global temperatures, why Earth's average temperature is warming, and how different factors influence the energy balance of our planet.

items.title: I can apply Wien's law to compare solar radiation and Earth's emission
items.what: The Sun at about 5778 K emits radiation peaking in visible wavelengths (around 500 nm). Earth at about 288 K emits radiation peaking in infrared wavelengths (around 10 μm). This difference is crucial for the greenhouse effect.
items.why: Visible light from the Sun passes through glass and the atmosphere easily, but the longer-wavelength infrared emitted by Earth is absorbed by glass and greenhouse gases, trapping energy.
items.example: Using Wien's law: Sun's peak wavelength = 2.898 × 10⁻³ / 5778 = 501 nm (visible). Earth's peak wavelength = 2.898 × 10⁻³ / 288 = 10.1 μm (infrared).

subtopic.name: Global Warming and Climate
subtopic.what: This subtopic applies concepts of thermal energy transfer, electromagnetic radiation, and blackbody physics to understanding Earth's energy budget, the greenhouse effect, and global warming.
subtopic.why: Understanding the physics of climate helps explain how small changes in atmospheric composition can affect global temperatures, why Earth's average temperature is warming, and how different factors influence the energy balance of our planet.

items.title: I can explain climate change in terms of energy imbalance and thermal energy storage
items.what: Global warming occurs when Earth absorbs more energy than it radiates. The excess energy is stored mainly in the oceans (about 90%), with the remainder warming the atmosphere, land, and melting ice.
items.why: Understanding where excess energy goes explains why ocean temperatures and sea levels rise, why ice sheets melt, and why the effects of greenhouse gas emissions persist for long periods.
items.example: Mean global temperature has risen about 1°C above the 1951-1980 baseline. Most of the extra thermal energy has gone into the oceans, which have enormous heat capacity.
